title: Will the annual rate of inflation for the eurozone reach or exceed 7.0% in April 2022 (2022M04)?
preds: Extreme pressure at the moment due to conflict in Ukraine, expect to be above 7%

The reported inflation figure for Eurostats in March is 7.4% which is already above 7% for March, with energy prices continuing to rise the inflation figure for April is more likely to be above 7%. https://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/statistics-explained/index.php?title=Inflation_in_the_euro_area
Alreay at 7.4% for M03 - and there has been no reduction in oil prices or any significant components

Seven point five now 7.5 The euro area annual inflation rate was 7.4% in March 2022, up from 5.9% in February. A year earlier, the rate was 1.3%. European Union annual inflation was 7.8% in March 2022, up from 6.2% in February. A year earlier, the rate was 1.7%.Apr 21, 2022

Eurostat shows that the annual rate of inflation was 7.8% for March (2202M3).  With the continued Russian-Ukrainian war and supply chain issues as they are, there is little chance of a decrease in the inflation rate.
With current economic dynamic, it will most likely happen at the 7% level.
Conflict in Ukraine driving inflation rate.
US data is there,  UK data is there and the energy crisis is hitting the EU area hard.

The March numbers are out and a new record was set at % 7.5. While Energy prices have started to stablize, there doesn't appear to be anything on the Horizon that would significantly change the trajectory of inflation in the EU.
Very low chance now it won't.
Given that the EA11 and EA12 estimate is now at 7.5% for March and that the E19 countries have followed this level for the whole charted table,  likelihood is very high.
Seems very likely with pay rise season, tight jobs market and fuel cost inflation on top of food inflation.  Going all out and saying yes.
Still think this will reach the target level due to pressure from conflict.
With uncertainty and conflict in Ukraine impacting heavily on the EU, this highly likely.
Estimated at 7.5% for Eu12.  That has tracked the same rate at the 19 countries so increasing

According to the German Retail Association (HDE), consumers should prepare for another wave of price hikes for everyday goods and groceries.
[...]
With Russia’s invasion hitting economies and the supply chain harder, yet another series of price increases is on the horizon. 
“The second wave of price increases is coming, and it will certainly be in double figures,” Sanktjohanser warned.
https://www.thelocal.de/20220401/german-consumers-to-be-hit-by-further-price-hikes-in-supermarkets/ --------
German retailer Aldi Nord will raise its prices by an average of 20-50% due to an increase in production costs, local media reported on Sunday [Apr 3]
[...]
Meanwhile, the German Retail Federation (HDE) has warned that the price hikes are likely to continue in the coming days in almost all supermarkets due to the effects of Russia's war on Ukraine and increase in energy costs.
https://www.aa.com.tr/en/economy/german-retailer-aldi-nord-to-raise-prices-by-20-50-on-monday/2554218
7.5% in March (up from 5.9% in February) and very likely to stay above 7% in April.
It's already up to 7.5% in March. No signs of it going down for the month of April specially given commodities prices and energy crisis due to Russian invasion of Ukraine.
It's already up to 7.5% in March. No signs of it going down for the month of April specially given commodities prices and energy crisis due to Russian invasion of Ukraine.

It looks like it's going to be about 7.5% for March. That would put the index at 114.52. If the index ends up at 114.52 for March and remains constant through April, then the inflation rate would be 114.52/107.14 (Apr 21 value) = 1.0689 => 6.88%. So if prices continue to go up at all, and it is widely expected that they will, then the annual inflation rate will reach or exceed 7.0% in April. Energy prices, which are driving most of the current surge in prices, remain high and are expected to remain high through April.
https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/CP0000EZ19M086NEST
https://www.politico.eu/article/germanys-imported-energy-prices-more-than-doubled-in-february/
https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/german-inflation-reach-over-7-march-state-data-suggest-2022-03-30/

Have to hand it to belikewater (not pinging to preserve attention) - they were right indeed. The preliminary is over 7% (https://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/databrowser/view/prc_hicp_manr/default/table?lang=en), and also speaking to various suppliers across Europe, a lot of planned price increases by large businesses seem to be scheduled for around April 15-18, with domino effects on the rest of the supply chain - leaving very little flexibility for any corrections downwards to occur based on relaxed energy price pressures, even if these were to occur.  While I do not think it is completely impossible we stay just below 7.0%, I think the chance of that happening is sub-1% at this point. May readjust if revised data significantly change the outlook. Hopefully, I will do better with this prediction that folks at the ECB.
First estimate for Euro aera for 03/22 has just been published - annual rate of change for March is estimated at 7.5 precent. Seems likely that this rate will continue into April.
With the conflict in Ukraine still unresolved, there is a good chance that the rate of inflation will go above the target level.

The March 2022 (2022M03) reading for the eurozone came it at 7.5%, already .5% above the threshold on the back of elevated energy prices. I'm leaving a a 1:20 chance or 5% chance that the energy prices drastically reduce pulling in inflation. But realistically it seems unlikely we will see a 0.5% drop in inflation over the next month with the ongoing conflict in Ukraine.

I put it at less than 1% that annual inflation drops by 0.5 percentage points in a month. That would be a very fast drop under any circumstances but with current global trends should be effectively impossible.
German annual inflation up more than 2 percentage points month over month
Germany just announced 7.2% and there is no downward trend in short term sight

Up from 46%. Increasing signs of food costs continuing to rise, continuing logjams with global supply chains, and general instability caused by this most recent Russian invasion of Ukraine are all contributing factors to the changed prediction.
Inflation still rising so will hedge forward to the crowd level
Supply chain, bail out money, oil issues, war issues... all trending up.

CPI Inflation is on the rise, but it is also very much explained by oil and gas price inflation.
But I believe that there will be excess inflation above oil and gas inflation as food prices, wages, and manufactured produkts such as cars, fridges increase in price as well.  I therefore land at a slight overweight for above 7% estimate
With the Ukraine invasion and pressure on EU economies, there is a high prospect that inflation rates will be pushed higher.

"According to the Munich-based economics institute, inflation is expected to rise from 5.1 to 6.1 percent in March. This would be the steepest rise in consumer prices since 1982."
https://www.thelocal.de/20220323/german-consumer-prices-set-to-rise-steeply-amid-war-in-ukraine/
I suspect this will be an underestimate. And that's just Germany.
Seems much higher than the historic values. Not sure how the Ukraine situation affects this, though.
Shifting up toward the crowd a bit.
Oil and Natural gas prices will go higher, past several months are trending higher and things are getting worse in Europe.

annual rate of inflation > 7% 			
since 1992, this never happened

F2022M04	7.582888222

Seems to be quite a high likelihood, having reached record rates in February, exceeding projections and projections for the end of March are close to 6.5% and the final target, with the situation in Ukraine making the energy situation worse and risks driving this up further still.

Still not fully convinced about the implied 146bps average increase per month in the index level required for the index to hit 7% in April, i guess March`s numbers will throw more light . Till than raising my estimate to factor in the uncertainty. For context the index rose 104bps in Feb 22
https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/CP0000EZ19M086NEST

Per HICP methodology, most prices are gathered mid month, but food and energy (main drivers of a possible spike) are gathered over a "period of more than one week". That's vague but it implies to me that the late Feb spike in energy prices may have been partly captured in the February data
https://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/statistics-explained/index.php?title=HICP_methodology UK Nat gas April futures are below where they were at end of Feb (https://www.theice.com/products/910/UK-Natural-Gas-Futures/data?marketId=5253318&span=1 )
Looks similar in Netherlands (https://www.barchart.com/futures/quotes/TG*1 ) Looks like ECB forecasted HICP inflation to peak ~5.8% in the next few months per chart 3 in the following link. Seems like almost certainly a lowball to me but it's one data point. It's lower than Goldman's 7.7% July forecast from 10 days ago, but 10 days ago nat gas futures were also ~25% higher than they are now.
https://www.ecb.europa.eu/pub/projections/html/ecb.projections202203_ecbstaff~44f998dfd7.en.html

Very much swayed by @belikewater, though not as brave as them to go full out. In particular, I wonder whether any large declaratory action by the EC could lead to correction in energy markets (remember that UvdL wants to lead a geopolitical commission, and this is the best shot at demonstrating that, so I would be slightly more optimistic on the chances of the Commission taking big leaps), and so within the next month (combined with seasonal energy price fluctuations) I do think there is a non-significant chance that April could cool the rise and it ends up being just below 7%.  Will absolutely have to see and update based on how severe the March numbers are (estimate released on April 1, full data April 21 as per eurostat release schedule).

A huge jump between January and February, and that was (mostly) before the war in Ukraine started. I think it's quite likely March's number will beover 7.0%, and this being an annualised rate will make it difficult to drop off much without actively falling prices.

February currently reporting in at 5.9%, or 0.8% above January. While that was certainly an oversized move and an uncommon one, it would not at all be very strange to see a +1.1% move in 2 months due to energy and food prices, resulting from the war.

I'd be at 99%-100% that Mar 22 inflation will be >= 7.0%. Could there be an unexpected, early termination to the war in Ukraine, leading to Russian troop withdrawals and drops in energy and food prices? Not likely, and it would probably take that and more to bring April 22 inflation under 7.0%.

Although a 1.1% increase is very big it is not beyond reality.  There was already a 0.8% jump from July to August 21 and from October to November 21.  With the significant impact in fuel and grain prices in the region in the last four weeks, an increase that big is plausible

It doesn't appear that the Eurozone expanded the money supply quite as much as the US did (I haven't done enough research to validate that hypothesis though). If my intuition is correct, we should be near the peak of this cycle.

Agreeing with various other forecasters here, that 7% is not impossible but that a 1.1% increase would be a lot. The increase through 2021 has been quite steady (average increase rate was roughly 0.42 percentage points per month). However, the war in Ukraine  serves an important factor of uncertainty. According to Eurostat, energy contributed most to the increase in February (https://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/documents/2995521/14358239/2-17032022-AP-EN.pdf/7bd82074-c752-a9bf-dfce-8e9b4eaf666e?t=1647426403308). Other goods are contributing too, but to a much lesser extent.
My initial estimate is slightly below 40% - to be updated once new data is released (see Eurostat schedule for HICP releases: https://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/documents/272892/10984304/HICP-release-schedule.pdf/). The initial 5.8% estimate  for February 2022 was quite accurate given that with yesterday's release the figure was only corrected by 0.1%. So the release  of March estimates on April 1 will be crucial for updating my estimate.
Already over this level in 8 of the 19 countries, albeit smaller economies.   War instability and challenges due to sanctions likely to keep things going upward.

5.8% was a record high for the Eurozone in February 2022. It seems that 5% annual inflation rate is a new norm, going up another 2% would be difficult to imagine right now. If another crisis takes hold (beyond Ukraine) this may be a possibility, but I’m not seeing the indicators currently. (https://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/documents/2995521/14083883/2-07012022-AP-EN.pdf/49039c42-31ea-3513-8307-eece31d6b25a)

Inflationary measures are always based on the index increase compared to the same period last year.  I can’t see the index,  ht given that last year we know the increase was relatively low over the mid year period, when we compare to the same period this year which is likely to increase, this means inflation is likely to be on the high end. Influences on inflationary are fuel and food prices,  it of which are likely to be a good bit higher in Europe than they were last year.   I think given the likely position compared to last year, 7pc is very possible.
Dropping on basis that commodity markets have not increased materially since end of Feb and we have had some good news on the Ukraine front.
My outside view is calculated from the z-score of such an event, taking previous monthly differences as the population. The resulting probability is 30%, which is then adjusted for current events.

I thought I'd include a note here about how inflation is calculated. First of all, there is a price index. Here are the HICP index values used for this forecast: https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/CP0000EZ19M086NEST Year-on-year ("yoy") inflation is always calculated compared to the inflation index value for the same month last year.
Example: Feb 22 index = 111.74, Feb 21 index = 105.54. Divide the recent value by last year's value: 111.74 / 105.54 = 1.059. Subtract 1: 1.059 - 1 = 0.059. Multiply by 100%: 0.059 * 100% = 5.9%. Feb 22 yoy inflation was 5.9%. To see what the month-on-month ("mom") inflation has been, compare the index value of one month to that of the month before.
Example: Feb 22 index = 111.74, Jan 22 index = 110.70. Divide the recent value by last month's value: 111.74 / 110.70 = 1.009. Subtract 1: 1.009 - 1 = 0.009. Multiply by 100%: 0.009 * 100% = 0.9%. If mom inflation 0.9%, then we find the current month's index value by multiplying the previous month's index value by 1.009.
Example: Jan 22 index = 110.70. Feb 22 mom inflation is 0.9%. Then Feb 22 index = 111.70 * 1.009 = 111.70. (It's actually 111.74; there's a small rounding error.) If mom inflation is 0.9% one month and 0.8% the next month, then the index gets multiplied by 1.009 * 1.008.
Example: Feb 22 index value is 111.74. April 22 index value would be 111.74 * 1.009 * 1.008 = 113.65. If inflation were constant every month, then the yoy inflation would be the mom inflation multiplied together 12 times (i.e., to the power of 12).
Example: If mom inflation were constant at 0.9%, then the index value would be multiplied by 1.009 each month. Then yoy inflation would be (1.009^12 - 1) * 100% = 11.4%. If inflation continued at 0.9% mom through April, the index value would be 1.009 (0.9% inflation for Feb-Mar) * 1.009 (0.9% inflation for Mar-Apr) * 111.74 (the Feb index value) = 113.76. Then yoy inflation for Apr 22 would be (113.76 / 107.14 (Apr 21 value) - 1) * 100% = 6.2%. With yoy inflation at 5.9% for Feb 22, it doesn't make a lot of sense to say we need to "add" 1.1% inflation to reach 7.0%. That 5.9% is relative to Feb 21, and our 7.0% in April will need to be relative to Apr 22. And inflation is multiplied, not added. Reaching 7.0% in April 22 is not equivalent to "adding" 0.55% inflation in March and April, except in the very loosest sense. To see 7% inflation for Apr 22, the index value would need to be 107.14 (April 21 value) * 1.07 (7% inflation) = 114.64. That would mean that we'd need to see (114.64 / 111.74 (Feb 22 index value) - 1) * 100% = 2.6% inflation from Feb 22 to Apr 22. That's a 2-month period. If inflation were constant throughout this period, we'd need to see the square root of 1.026 = 1.026^(1/2) = 1.013 => 1.3% mom inflation in March and April to reach 7.0% yoy inflation in April 22. To summarize:
1. Yoy inflation is calculated by comparing this year's index value to last year's index value.
2. Inflation rates are multiplied together, not added. Index values are multiplied by inflation rates to get new index values.
3. Feb 22 mom inflation was 0.9%.
4. To reach 7.0% yoy inflation in Apr 22, we'd need to see approx. 1.3% mom inflation in both March and April (or higher one month and lower the other month). Note that Feb 22 saw 0.9% mom inflation, with nearly all of Feb before the invasion of Ukraine and energy and food price spikes. It seems likely to me (see my previous forecasts for details) that March 22 mom inflation would exceed Feb 22 mom inflation by more than 0.4%, given that energy price changes alone could cause March mom inflation to be perhaps over 3%.

If energy costs are up ~30% *mom*, and energy is 11% of the HICP, then energy costs alone will make the HICP go up ~0.3*0.11=~0.033 => ~3.3% *mom*. Before, energy costs have gone up ~30% *yoy* (possibly ~30% yoy for Feb 21 to Feb 22; 25% yoy for Dec 20 to Dec 21: https://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/web/products-eurostat-news/-/edn-20220210-2 )
I'm not sure energy costs will be ~30% mom for Feb-Mar 22, but I've seen some measures that suggest this general range is possible. "FRANKFURT, March 16 (Reuters) - War in Ukraine and the threat of energy supply disruptions have driven gas and electricity bills for German householders entering into new contracts to record highs and will filter down to others over time, data showed on Wednesday. A household using 20,000 kilowatt hours (kWh) per year and agreeing a new annual contract in March had to pay a record 3,305 euros ($3,632), equivalent to 16.5 cents/kWh, price comparison portal Check24 said. That is 62% above the monthly price in December. "Consumers have seen an unprecedented wave of gas price hikes this winter," said Steffen Suttner, Managing Director Energy at Check24, pointing to soaring wholesale prices. The Russia-Ukraine war could bring further increases due to uncertainty about the availability of gas, said Check24. Half of Germany's 41.5 million households use gas for heating. The European Gas Spot index at German trading hub THE is up 93% this month from the previous month. Electricity prices are also at record levels. A new 5,000 kWh annual supply contract costs an average of 2,098 euros, or 42 cents/kWh, 23% more than in December, Check24 said. For professional buyers, prices on the EEX bourse this month are 283 euros/MWh, 130% more than in February, which means households face more increases due to utilities' higher purchasing costs, Suttner said."
https://www.reuters.com/business/energy/german-gas-power-prices-households-new-highs-2022-03-16/ Energy costs in the HICP were up 28.8% yoy for Jan 22, and 32% for Feb 22.
https://tradingeconomics.com/euro-area/inflation-cpi
So, given the numbers in the Reuters article above, it's quite possible that household energy costs could even be up by >30% mom for Mar 22.

Taking the outside view I'll roughly base it on since 2021M05 it's grown by 3.1% over 8 months, an average of 0.39% per month. Three months of that would put it at 5.1 + 0.39*3 = 6.3%. So I'll lean toward no due to base rate. But I'm close to 50% because of the invasion of Russia and the increase in oil prices and other pandemic instabilities. February is showing pretty high preliminary numbers in the other categories.

Inflation trending up clearly, its a question of will it hit that high 7.0% threshold.  Linreg for eurozone since May'21 puts it at 6.983%, which I believe would round up. UK inflation has pretty closely mirrored Eurozone inflation but lower by 0.1-0.2%, and the BoE's prior forecast was a peak of 7.25% in April, which as of yesterday they revised higher (https://www.france24.com/en/live-news/20220317-boe-agrees-third-straight-rate-hike-as-inflation-soars). Goldman's older forecast was a peak of 7.7 in July for the Eurozone (https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-03-10/goldman-sees-euro-area-economy-shrinking-inflation-close-to-8#:~:text=Goldman%20Sachs%20predicts%20euro%2Darea,to%20increase%202.2%25%20in%202023.) but they don't provide a timeline for it. I would expect faster growth in the next 2 months and slowing into the peak before turning back downward though, which would likely put us at 7.0% or higher. The US fed remains hawkish as well (https://www.thestreet.com/markets/stocks-slip-lower-as-markets-re-set-after-hawkish-fed-rate-hike).  The worry for most is the soaring cost of energy, especially the forecasted shortfalls in the oil market due to Russian sanctions mentioned in the BoE article, which will be most acute in the next couple months before OPEC or whoever decides to pump more oil, or new non-Russian sourcing can be found for countries enforcing US sanctions, or demand adjusts downward. There's also worries about large increases in other commodity prices as a result of the Russian invasion, and I don't forecast that resolving any time soon, so those fears will probably materialize.  The main against case here is simply the threshold. If it lands at 6.9%, a forecast for 7.0% is still 100% wrong. Linreg puts it at 7.0% exactly, but most forecasts are for a peak between April and July, and all else equal we expect growth to slow as we approach that peak, not continue linearly. Historically also, months with large jumps tend to be followed by lower or flat growth the next month, and we just had a month with a large jump (0.8%). We need to average 0.55% for the next 2 months to hit 7.0%, so a flatter month in March (if it happens) would make 7.0% much less likely.  Overall, expectations do seem to be for a >7.0% level in April, but the choice of threshold does mean that this will likely be a tight finish, and a close of just below 7.0% needs to be accounted for.

Right now, the rate of growth for inflation would have to increase substantially to meet 7.0% in April 22. The big drivers in Eurozone inflation right now have been energy prices, even before the recent geopolitical unrest. The prices in food and other consumption goods (ex. cars) haven't risen at the same rate, in addition to that wage growth hasn't picked up as much as in the US (https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/euro-zone-firms-see-wages-rising-by-3-or-more-ecb-says-2022-02-04/).
This leads me to believe that such a big jump is fairly unlikely to happen, especially considering that any non-military conclusion of the Ukraine conflict will be well-received by energy markets.

Initial Forecast 3/17:  I'd put the highest probability of being between 6-7, much lower probability of exceeding 7%.  Energy prices have moderated in recent days and markets are becoming more stable as investors gain more understanding of the response to Russia's invasion.  European countries are also less vulnerable to shifts in oil price: "In the U.S., when the price of oil goes up or down 10%, the price of gasoline will change roughly 7%, while it will change just about 3% in Europe, where taxes are a larger portion — and the cost of oil a smaller portion — of the price."  Therefore I would expect more consistency in the inflation rate in Europe between Feb, Mar, April. https://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?dataset=prc_hicp_manr&lang=en
https://www.kiplinger.com/personal-finance/shopping/cars/604410/gas-prices-around-the-world
Inflation rates have already be growing so while the war will likely increase this I don't anticipate the rate of increase to more than double.

Since mid-pandemic, inflation has skyrocketed in the Eurozone. See attached link:  https://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/statistics-explained/index.php?title=Inflation_in_the_euro_area#Euro_area_annual_inflation_rate_and_its_main_components I am going to forecast that with the energy crisis due to Ukraine and the rising cost of food, post-pandemic, that this level of inflation is highly likely.

Here are the HICP values: https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/CP0000EZ19M086NEST
The April 2021 value was 107.14. The Jan 2022 value was 110.70. 110.70/107.14 = 1.033 => 3.3% inflation from April 2021 to Jan 2022. 
Feb 2022 will probably be ~1.058 * 105.54 = 111.67. 111.67 / 107.14 = 1.042 => 4.2% inflation from April 2021 to Feb 2022.
This will be a very tight question. With the recent trend in price increases, 6.0% would be pretty likely. Will the invasion of Ukraine cause prices to increase enough to reach 7.0%? March prices will be higher, with energy shocks. And April will probably add a bit more of an increase beyond March. Later edit:
"In Euro Area, the inflation rate is calculated using the weighted average of the Harmonised Index of Consumer Price (HICP) aggregates. The main components of the HICP are: food, alcohol and tobacco (19 percent of the total weight), energy (11 percent), non-energy industrial goods (29 percent) and services (41 percent). The HICP aggregates are computed as the weighted average of each country’s HICP components. The weight of a country is its share of household final monetary consumption expenditure in the total of the country’s group. The local HICPs are supplied to the Eurostat by the National Statistical Institutes."
https://tradingeconomics.com/euro-area/inflation-cpi With food prices going up globally, and food, energy and other commodity shocks from the Ukraine war, it does seem likely to me that 7.0% will be reached. To reach 7.0%, the index would need to reach 1.07*107.14 = 114.64. Feb 2022 is probably at 111.67. Then March and April would need to be approx. (114.64/111.67)^(1/2) = 1.0132 => 1.3% month-on-month inflation. Given that Jan-Feb inflation was likely at ~0.9%, I think 1.3% or higher will likely be reached for Feb-Mar and Mar-April. Fuel and food prices have soared.

All the major economies of the eurozone are roughly 3-5% and are without exception estimated to be increasing. Many east European nations are approaching double figures already, with Lithuania and Estonia now estimated at over 12%. It looks like there will be further fallout from the Ukraine invasion due to scarcity of supplies, the energy crisis, and other economic issues which will gradually put pressure on rates over months rather than weeks. 
I think the trend will continue upwards, and a 1.2% increase over 2 months has already happened twice in the last year, but it could well just fall short by April.

No the high was 2021@ 2.43
“The commission estimated that annual inflation in the euro area will rise from 2.6% in 2021 to 3.5% in 2022, to then come down to 1.7% in 2023. The outlook for inflation, but also for the overall economy in Europe, is also dependent on tensions between Ukraine and Russia.Feb 10, 2022”

5.8% in February, with a 0.9% month-on-month increase. With fuel and commodity prices much higher than a year ago, this is likely to go up further in the next two months, but 1.2% more? https://tradingeconomics.com/euro-area/inflation-rate-mom With, month on month increase in March 2021 of 0.9%, followed by 0.6% in April 2021,  to hit 7.0% year-on-year in April 2022, we would have to see an average month-on-month increase of 1.35% per month in the next two months, which would be a stretch.

If the 5.8% estimate for February turns out to be correct, that will be a 0.7% increase in one month. Once inflation starts to get going like this, it usually moves pretty quickly. At that rate it will hit 7%. And now there is a war going on in eastern europe, creating sanctions and shutting down supply lines on food and energy; something that wasn't happening in February. Don't listen to any "expert" talk about inflation who didn't predict that inflation would get this high or who said that inflation was going to be transitory. They are all demand side economists. It was the economists who understand that inflation is always a monetary phenomenon who predicted inflation would get to this level, and they are saying it is going higher and not going away.

5.8% estimated for February.  Climbing to 7% not out of the question, but energy prices seem to have moderated a bit in the past few days.  Wildcard would be a China-based shutdown because of Covid, roiling the supply chain.
We should also look at currency fluctuations. The euro is weakening against the dollar, and (for example) the Polish złoty is weakening against the euro and the dollar.
Goldman forecasts peak of 7.7% in July. That's a 2% increase in 5 months after the 5.8% rate in Feb. so we might expect 6.5% in April if it's linear, I'll put it a little below 50-50

As of this forecast, the latest annual inflation reading was 5.8% as of February an all time high dating back to at least 1990 (The data I was looking at) and up a large 0.7% from January. This means an average of 0.6%/month over the next 2 reading for this to exceed the 7% inflation meaning this massive spike in inflation in the eurozone must continue to rise at its current rapid rate. While conflict in Ukraine has put a large amount of pressure on Energy and Food prices, it appears that the recent spike in global oil has already started to retreat a bit from it's recent highs as alternatives to Russian Energy are beginning to take shape. While I expect inflation to remain high --probably even pushing a bit higher-- 2 straight months of 0.6% increases in inflation seems too aggressive unless Energy prices continue to rise at it's recent insane rates.
This one is a close call- France and Germany (huge proportion of Euro Area Economy) have quite low inflation at present but inflationary pressures are working through over coming months for sure.
